Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls you in the middle of the night, crying, because they just received some devastating family news.
Expectation2: Recite and reflect on the Quran
Situation2: A relaxed evening lies ahead with no other commitments.
Story: I had been looking forward to this evening all week—a rare, quiet night with no obligations, just me, my prayer mat, and the Quran. I’d planned to recite and reflect, to reconnect with my faith after a hectic few days. The house was silent, the world outside already asleep. I had just opened the Quran when my phone buzzed, shattering the calm. It was my closest friend, her name lighting up the screen. I answered, and immediately heard her sobbing. Through broken words, she told me her family had just received terrible news. She needed me—needed someone to listen, to comfort her, to just be there. As she cried, I felt torn. My heart ached for her, but I also felt the pull of my spiritual commitment, the peace I’d been craving. I wanted to be the friend she needed, but I also wanted to honor my intention to spend this time with Allah. The weight of both expectations pressed on me, and I sat there, phone in hand, caught between two worlds, unsure which to choose.
